intro: Galium pseudoaparine, commonly known as false agrimony, is a herbaceous perennial plant belonging to the Rubiaceae family. It is characterized by its slender, creeping stems and opposite, ovate leaves that are typically covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, white or pale green flowers in clusters, which are usually borne on slender pedicels. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodland areas or along stream banks. Galium pseudoaparine is known for its ability to spread via rhizomes, forming dense mats that can dominate certain ecological niches.
